"The Gods of the Hearth Exist for Us Still": George Eliot's Critiques of Rationalism

George Eliot's 1856 translation of Spinoza's Ethics was finally published in 2019. It draws scholarly attention to her role at the forefront of the English reception of continental rationalism. Before she became the famous Victorian novelist, Eliot was an active member of the Rosehill Circle, and made the first translations of David Strauss, Ludwig Feuerbach, and Baruch Spinoza into English. However, the growing appreciation of Eliot's philosophical career throws the themes of her novels in sharp relief, since Eliot's critical responses to triumphal atheism and the moral benefits of scientific progress run throughout her novels. In Silas Marner (1861), her masterpiece Middlemarch (1872), and other novels, narrators intone, and characters discover that scientific advancement cannot overcome the role of chance in human affairs. For this reason, they realize, time-honored moral and religious beliefs can neither be completely rationalized nor rendered obsolete.
